bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. ROHRABACHER:H.R. 3830.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:This bill follows the Constitutional prerogatives ofCongress under Article I, Section 8, pertaining to theclauses to ``to regulate commerce with foreign nations.''[Page H182]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

summary.text:
Prohibits defense articles or services from being provided to Iraq unless the President certifies to Congress that Iraq agrees to not use such articles or services or any other U.S.-provided defense articles of defense services within the Kurdistan region of Iraq without the consent of the Kurdistan Regional Government.

States that if the President determines that Iraq has used defense articles or defense services in violation of such restrictions no further defense articles or defense services may be provided to Iraq unless the President certifies to Congress that: (1) Iraq has withdrawn such articles or services from Kurdistan, and (2) the Kurdistan Regional Government has approved the provision to Iraq of such further defense articles or services.

bill.title: To restrict the provision of defense articles and defense services to the Government of Iraq, and for other purposes.

item.title: To restrict the provision of defense articles and defense services to the Government of Iraq, and for other purposes.
To restrict the provision of defense articles and defense services to the Government of Iraq, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
